results.title: English without tears
results.creator_credit: Two Cities Films, Anatole de Grunwald, Sydney Box, William Sassoon and Harold French
results.brief_description: Set in Geneva Switzerland during World War II “English without tears” is a gentle and entertaining romantic satire. The multi-plots within the film mainly focus on the small things that matter to people during wartime. An aristocratic family including an eccentric bird fancier (Margaret Rutherford) leaves for Geneva. The faithful butler joins the army and becomes lieutenant. The charming daughters falls for the butler who is successful in his new role. The plot becomes amusing as the story unfolds while the class barriers of peacetime relax and the romantic complications reveal themselves. A charming English studio film. Cast includes Michael Wilding, Margaret Rutherford, Lili Palmer and Penelope Ward.

results.title: English teaching tomorrow (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Discusses the problem of teaching english to resistant pupils who constantly use non-standard english. A teacher and an elementary school principal ask advice of linguists to help provide varying approaches to the problem.

results.title: English mahogany and brass bi-unial magic lantern
results.brief_description: The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories. Bi-unial lanterns use two lenses to create the illusion of movement.

constellations_primary.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_primary.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

results.title_for_label: English mahogany and brass bi-unial magic lantern
results.description:
The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories.

Originally, lanternists used candles or gaslight to illuminate their slides, which usually limited their projections to one lens. When limelight was invented in the 1800s, it not only produced brighter, clearer projections but also allowed lanternists to control the light source, leading to more creative approaches and inventions. One was the bi-unial lantern, like this one, which uses two lenses to superimpose different slides onto the same screen to create the illusion of time or movement.
description_for_label:
The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories.

Originally, lanternists used candles or gaslight to illuminate their slides, which usually limited their projections to one lens. When limelight was invented in the 1800s, it not only produced brighter, clearer projections but also allowed lanternists to control the light source, leading to more creative approaches and inventions. One was the bi-unial lantern, like this one, which uses two lenses to superimpose different slides onto the same screen to create the illusion of time or movement.

results.title: English lyrics
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Literature Appreciation”.
The lyrics of Tennyson, Keats, Wordsworth, Shelley, Shakespeare, Browning and others are presented. Viewing such scenes as Dover Beach, Westminser Bridge, and the Shropshire country, students gain new appreciation and understanding of the work of poets.

results.title: English criminal justice
results.brief_description: An explanation of court procedure in England, showing the various types of courts and their particular functions. The cases range from a simple Petty Sessions case to a murder trial at the Old Bailey.

results.title: English children: life in the city
results.brief_description: Junior grade, social studies film showing English family life in the City of York, stressing daily activities of the children. Points out aspects of English home life and presents authentic events in a modern school, on the playground, at a cricket match, and at a grocery store. Concludes with a family holiday trip by train to a nearby seaside resort.
